title: My Honest Take on the Pear Tallow Balm
body:
Okay so I was just putting this stuff on my face and I realized I should probably write this down somewhere. My hands are still a little greasy. It’s this whipped tallow balm. Beef tallow. For your skin. I know, I know. It sounds like something you’d rub on a saddle, not your face. That’s what I thought too. But my skin was just… done. It was winter, like, the kind of winter where the air feels like it’s actively stealing moisture from your cheeks. I’d been using this fancy $48 cream from that place in the mall, you know the one with the blue jars. Nothing. My knuckles were cracking. My face felt tight all the time, like I was wearing a mask made of dry clay. I was desperate. I’d tried everything from the Walgreens on 5th, not the one by the highway, that one’s weird. Anyway. I saw someone talking about tallow balm on, I don’t know, some forum maybe. A beef tallow skincare thing. I was skeptical. Very. But I clicked on this little Etsy shop. The one with the pear-scented one. Pear! That seemed less intimidating. A gentle, fresh scent. I figured if I was gonna smear beef fat on myself, it should at least smell like fruit.

So I ordered it. The Whipped Tallow Balm in Pear. It showed up in this little jar. I opened it. Smelled like. I don’t know. Nice though. Not like meat. Just a soft, clean, fruity smell. Not perfume-y. Just… pleasant. I poked it. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. It was super soft, like it had been whipped forever. I put a tiny bit on the back of my hand. It felt… waxy for a second, then it just sort of vanished. My skin drank it. No greasy film. That was the first surprise.

## How I Started Using Tallow on My Face

Look, my routine before this was a mess. Serum, toner, moisturizer, night cream, eye cream… a whole production. It took ten minutes and my skin still felt like the desert. I’d stare at my sad, flaky cheek in the magnifying mirror and just sigh. One night, after washing my face, I just looked at the tallow jar. I thought, what’s the worst that could happen? I’ll break out and look like a teenager again. Big deal.

I scooped out a little. About the size of a pea. Rubbed it between my fingers to warm it up. It melted almost instantly into this silky oil. I patted it on my face. My forehead, cheeks, neck. I braced for grease. For clogged pores. For a shiny, weird face. But it just… sank in. My skin felt calm. Not oily. Not dry. Just… quiet. Like it finally got a drink of water after a long trip. I went to bed expecting to wake up a mess.

I didn’t. My face felt normal. Actually better than normal. It didn’t have that tight, itchy feeling when I smiled. That was day one.

The real test was my hands. My knuckles in winter are a disaster. Red, cracked, they’d sometimes bleed when I made a fist. I started using the tallow balm on them after doing dishes. Just a tiny dab. The cracks started healing. Not overnight, but within a few days, the redness went down. The skin stopped feeling like sandpaper. I told my sister about it. She was horrified. “You put what on your face?” But then she saw my hands. She stopped talking.

## Why Beef Tallow for Skin Actually Makes Sense

I got curious after it started working. So I looked it up. I’m not a scientist. But the basic idea is this: tallow from grass-fed cows is kinda similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So when you put it on, your skin recognizes it. It doesn’t just sit on top like a plastic wrap; it gets absorbed. It’s like giving your skin the building blocks it already knows how to use. This stuff is made in France, whipped to this crazy light texture. It’s for winter damage, dry patches, even chapped lips. I used it on my lips once when I couldn’t find my chapstick. Worked better.

It made a weird kind of sense. All those lab-made creams with fifty ingredients… my skin didn’t know what to do with them. This was simple. Beef fat, some pear scent, maybe a couple other natural things. That’s it. My switch to natural products wasn’t some big ethical thing at first. It was just… this worked and the other stuff didn’t. My whole natural skincare routine now is basically this jar and a gentle cleanser. That’s it. Two things. It’s embarrassingly simple.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of Tallow Balm Daily Use

So it’s been maybe a month now. Maybe six weeks? I lost track. The dramatic transformation you see in ads? Didn’t happen. I didn’t turn into a dewy goddess. But the real, quiet results are what made me a believer.

My skin just… stopped complaining. No more tightness after I shower. No more flaky patches around my nose when I put on makeup. My complexion is even. Not perfect, but even. It looks healthy. Not “glowing” in that fake way, just… content. My hands are actually presentable. I don’t hide them in my pockets anymore. That’s huge for me.

The best part is how simple it is. My tallow balm daily use is literally just: wash face, pat dry, scoop balm, apply. Done. Twenty seconds. It’s my morning and night thing. Sometimes I just use it at night if I’m lazy. It doesn’t care. It still works.

I was on a video call with my mom last week and she said, “Your skin looks good, what are you using?” I paused. I had to tell her. “Uh, it’s beef fat, Mom.” She laughed. Then she asked for the link. I’m on my second jar now. I got one for her too. The little Etsy shop I got it from has a few scents, but I’m sticking with Pear. It’s light. Doesn’t clash with anything. Just a clean, subtle sweetness.

## Would I Buy It Again?

Yeah. I already did. I’m looking at the jar right now. It’s about half gone. I’ll probably order another one soon so I don’t run out. That’s the real test, right? Repurchasing.

It’s not magic. It won’t erase wrinkles or turn back time. But if your skin is dry, or irritated, or just fussy and nothing seems to help… this might. It feels like a secret. A weird, beefy secret that actually works. I don’t know how else to say it. My skin is happy. I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.

Anyway. If you’re curious about switching to natural products and you’re tired of complicated routines that don’t deliver, this might be worth a shot. Start with your hands if you’re squeamish. That’s what I did.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yes. From what I understand, the fat composition is really close to what our skin produces naturally. So it absorbs deep instead of just coating the surface. It’s like giving your skin something it actually knows how to use.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
I was terrified of this. But no, for me it didn’t. It’s non-comedogenic, which means it shouldn’t clog pores. It sinks right in. My skin feels clear, not congested. If anything, it’s calmer.

**What does the Pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s not a strong perfume. It’s just a light, fresh, fruity smell. Like a ripe pear, but softer. Not candy-sweet. Just clean and pleasant. It fades pretty quick after you put it on. You mostly just smell… nothing, which I like.

So yeah. That’s my take. If your skin’s being difficult, might be worth a shot.
